subs.rawText:
It‚Äôs an information access problem.

I‚Äôd say that @SBTOutdoors posts TWO valuable kinds of information for people who treasure the things of nature in our region.

First, there are very interesting ways to learn and participate _right now_, like this seed-growing example. And‚Ä¶ https://t.co/9ZotzIH8pY

subs.text: Second, @SBTOutdoors posts excellent introductions to long-term opportunities, like this new-to-many-of-us nature preserve an hour up the shore from here. Two kinds of truly valuable postings for real readers in our region. But then‚Ä¶ [link]

subs.text: On social media, these excellent postings about life in our region are mixed together, and then slip down the screen into the archive. Unless you know to look for a particular posting, a reader can really only wander from screen to screen, an ineffective search method. And‚Ä¶

subs.text:
So, it‚Äôs an information access problem.

The @SBTOutdoors writer performs two kinds of valuable work, and the web publishing tools employed by the newspaper chain are not tuned finely enough to preserve and foreground both the real short and long-term value there. In conclusion‚Ä¶

So, it‚Äôs an information access problem.

subs.text: 1/5 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I‚Äôd hear him talk about a number called degree days, which comes from a formula that includes the mean monthly temperature.
subs.rawText: 1/5 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I‚Äôd hear him talk about a number called degree days, which comes from a formula that includes the mean monthly temperature.

subs.text: 2/5 The number of degree days for the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas the company should have on hand to sell next March.
subs.rawText: 2/5 The number of degree days for the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas the company should have on hand to sell next March.

subs.text: 3/5 But they‚Äôd need an extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than other recent years. Each March has its own unpredictable degree day total, when all is said and done.
subs.rawText: 3/5 But they‚Äôd need an extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than other recent years. Each March has its own unpredictable degree day total, when all is said and done.

subs.text: 4/5 Our local natural gas company stored gas reserves in a porous layer of rock beneath the north side of the metro area. Buy it cheap in the summer, pump it underground, and pump it out later when it's needed.
subs.rawText: 4/5 Our local natural gas company stored gas reserves in a porous layer of rock beneath the north side of the metro area. Buy it cheap in the summer, pump it underground, and pump it out later when it's needed.

subs.text: 5/5 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that‚Äôs thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that‚Äôs thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.
subs.rawText: 5/5 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that‚Äôs thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that‚Äôs thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.

subs.text:
Responsibility
to renewable systems

would be a satisfying
and enduring cultural story

much better than our current one,

which glorifies the frantic 
and ecstatic strip-mining
of the planet‚Äôs resources,

crashing the natural systems
that make the resources
in the first place.

subs.text:
First day of spring semester, 1977, walking on a campus sidewalk. Ahead on the cement, I see a piece of paper money. Picked it up, looked around, said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a $100 bill.‚Äù

The young woman walking behind me said, ‚ÄúI should have gotten out of bed five minutes earlier today.‚Äù

subs.text: March 3

1/3 The Stones are on the box, loud enough so I notice the drums. Next song, again it's the drums. I usually think the Stones are about the sting of the guitars and the backbone and sneer and syrup of the voice and the words, but no, tonight the drummer is the front man.
subs.rawText: 1/3 The Stones are on the box, loud enough so I notice the drums. Next song, again it's the drums. I usually think the Stones are about the sting of the guitars and the backbone and sneer and syrup of the voice and the words, but no, tonight the drummer is the front man.

subs.text: 2/3 Music teaches young people how to feel something, I think my sister said. Maybe that's the wound steel of the strings stretched and plucked, doing their part, but tonight the drums seem to say: don't just feel something, you'd better move.
subs.rawText: 2/3 Music teaches young people how to feel something, I think my sister said. Maybe that's the wound steel of the strings stretched and plucked, doing their part, but tonight the drums seem to say: don't just feel something, you'd better move.

subs.text: 3/3 The backbone, the attitude, well, we need that whenever we move out into the streets. The words might help us know why that is. Help us set sweet against bitter as we go.
subs.rawText: 3/3 The backbone, the attitude, well, we need that whenever we move out into the streets. The words might help us know why that is. Help us set sweet against bitter as we go.

subs.text: And then one of the cruel songs comes on.
subs.rawText: And then one of the cruel songs comes on.

subs.text: @cameronponsonby @blzzrd I grew up in a family of goalkeepers and goalie coaches in St. Louis, Missouri, one of the U.S.‚Äôs few real old football towns. Everyone I show this article to texts me saying, ‚ÄúYes!‚Äù My brother‚Äôs son said, ‚ÄúDad, you used to shout those same things at the TV when I was a kid.‚Äù

subs.text: March 1

When a person or a country decides to make war, no only do they destroy visible and tangible things, but they also steal hours of everyday life for years to come. Putin is a thief, one among many. [link]
